Queueing a job

August 21st, 2016

In the last blog post, I showed how I migrated a CLI load testing tool to a web application. Using the Phoenix framework, it was straight forward to get started and have early results. We could trigger a load test from a web page. When this test was over, the page would refresh to show the results. While this was exciting to begin with, it presents an issue. Waiting for a load test to finish can be long. During that waiting time, we are holding a connection open to the server. It wouldn’t be too hard to open many tabs, and launch long running tests before the server starts blowing up.

This week, I focused on making these tests asynchronous so that the connection to the server is released. By refreshing a “progress” page, it’s possible to see if the test is still running. In the world of Rails, it would be the equivalent of launching a job.

Not so fast

I thought at first that this was going to be an easy thing to do, wrong. Phoenix doesn’t come with a job framework like Rails do With a little bit of research, I found some open source frameworks like exq. While some of these libraries are most likely the right solution long term, I wanted to try something simpler.

In-memory queue

The simplest iteration I could think about

Limitation
